awd_titl_txt: DDRIG: An Historical Study of the Circulation and Growth of Medical Knowledge
awd_abstract_narration:
This research delves into the networks of Jewish physicians and surgeons who endured trials by the tribunals of the Holy Office of the Spanish Inquisition based in the Americas. The goal is to uncover how these practitioners circulated medical knowledge in the 17th-century Spanish Empire as they faced surveillance and prosecution by the Inquisition. In addition to the research conducted, these funds will also contribute to a digital humanities database project called Jews and Early Modern Medicine in the Atlantic World (JEMMAW). This webpage will feature timelines, maps, archival images, bibliographies, contextual information, and links to archival sources relevant to each practitioner. JEMMAW is intended as an open-access academic resource for the history of medicine, knowledge circulation, and the history of science in the Americas. It is designed for use by students of all levels as well as high school and college teachers. Archival research and analysis of collected documents serves as the primary methodology of data collection.

This research focuses on three questions: First, how did the popular policing and social ‘otherizing’ relied upon by the Inquisition hinder or otherwise affect the creation and circulation of medical knowledge? Second, did the Jewish nation function as a means of knowledge circulation for Jewish and crypto-Jewish medical practitioners? And lastly, How does the America’s position within narratives of history of science and history of medicine inform our interpretation of past medical practice? This research emphasizes the lived experiences and persecution of surgeons who lived within societies of popular policing, who still managed to produce and circulate valuable medical and scientific knowledge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report - DDRIG: An Historical Study of the Circulation and Growth of Medical Knowledge

  • Federal Award ID: 2147139
  • Report Submission Period: 03/01/2023 to 08/31/2023

This research worked to discover commercial networks and various means of medical knowledge circulation among Jewish medical practitioners interrogated and prosecuted by the Tribunal of the Holy Office of the Spanish Inquisition in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Considering the reliance of the Holy Office of the Inquisition on popular surveillance and suspicion in the context of the Gran Complicidad, to maintain the authority of the Catholic faith, how did Jewish and crypto-Jewish practitioners obtain and share their knowledge?

This project works to answer the following questions:

  1. How did popular surveillance and ?othering? relied upon by the Holy Office hinder or otherwise affect the creation and circulation of medical knowledge?
  2. Did the Portuguese-Jewish Nation ?Na?ao? function as a means of knowledge circulation for crypto-Jewish medical practitioners?
  3. How does Latin America?s position within narratives of history of science and medicine inform our interpretation of past medical practice?

 

 

In addition to facilitating research for the researcher?s dissertation, this research will be presented at Oregon State University?s Qualitative Methods Research Cluster symposium 2023. As dissertation research comes to a close, co-PI Aimee D?vila Hisey is also preparing two manuscripts for submission to academic journals for publication consideration. The first manuscript emphasizes religious identity in this context as a spectrum rather than the perceived historical binary of Christian or Jewish. The second manuscript looks at slave trading records noting health issues of purchased slaves and the role that Portuguese-Jewish practitioners played in the Transatlantic Slave Trade.

This DDRIG also facilitated the creation of Jews and Early Modern Medicine in the Atlantic World (JEMMAW). This digital humanities database highlights the crypto-Jewish medical practitioners studied. Each practitioner biography contains a brief summary, timelines of their lives, story maps tracing the circulation of their medical knowledge, archival images from documents pertaining to their lives and Inquisitorial trials, and bibliographies of secondary sources that include that practitioner. JEMMAW also offers links to paleographical resources to aid in deciphering sixteenth- and seventeenth-century trial documents, as well as contextual pages highlighting the means of knowledge acquisition and transmission in early modern Europe and the Atlantic.
